results.title: An Interview with Jim Dickson
results.brief_description: Commodore Jim Dickson came from a Naval family and joined the cadets at 13. As a ship navigator off the coast of Vietnam in 1965, he experienced the pressure of being responsible for the welfare of the crew and the ship. He reflects on the turbulence of the era, the bonds that are formed in times of adversity and the terrible waste wrought by war.

group.title: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [September 2009]

group_siblings.title: An Interview with Brigadier John P.A. Deighton
An Interview with Brigadier Keith Rossi
An Interview with Major General Jim Hughes

production_dates.notes: Workshop was in August 2009 but project completed in September 2009

results.title: An Interview with Alf Argent
results.brief_description: When Alf finished school, World War II had started. He signed up but was not called up for service until after he graduated from Duntroon at age 18. Alf then tells the story of his journey, through the Korean War, the Vietnam War to training in Europe and how he got to see the effects of war first-hand. A distinguised man who led an extraordinary life.

results.title: An Interview with Jessie Perkins
results.brief_description: Jessie Perkins was 16 when World War II started. When she was 18, Japan entered the war and Jessie was keen to contribute, but her dad wouldn’t let her. She tells of how her convinced her father to let her go, her time at the Australian Army Service Corp in Geelong and, ultimately, her long and distinguished career in the army.

results.title: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [September 2009]
results.brief_description: 10 interviews with Victorian war veterans, created as part of the “In our words : Stories from Victorian veterans” Digital Storytelling workshop in August 2009, with the support of the Department of Planning and Community Development, the Shrine of Remembrance, and the Victorian Veterans Council.

results.title: An Interview with Brigadier Keith Rossi
results.brief_description: Brigadier Keith Rossi went to join up but needed to lie about his age to do so. He tells of his time in the army with humour, capturing the cameraderie that helped alleviate the horror of war. In his time serving, he went from the Middle East, to New Guinea and, later, Vietnam, from Private to Brigadier.

results.title: An Interview with Wes Bailey
results.brief_description: With a vibrant sense of humour, Wes Bailey recounts his various postings as a signaller during World War II. Long hot days of being eaten alive by mozzies as well as the expected pleasures of fruit and vegetables have nothing on the most significant posting of Bailey’s career, as husband to fellow signaller Phil Bailey.

results.title: The Yellow-box eucalypt
results.creator_credit: Des Surkitt, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Des Surkitt pays tribute to the 27 fallen soldiers in one of the worst accidents in the Australian Army’s history. In Kapooka, an explosion during a training exercise, took the lives of all but one of the young soldiers. This event had a profound effect on Des, more so as he had just completed the training program the week before. Despite his good fortune, Des honours these lost men and reflects on why they have been forgotten by their own country.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Des Surkitt, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: An Interview with Evelyn Warner
results.brief_description: Evelyn Warner was in London when World War II was declared. As a very young cadet, Warner cycled around the countryside delivering messages. Then one day she had an encounter with a ‘doddlebug’, an unmanned plane designed to crash and burn, that left her red-faced.
results.description: Evelyn Warner was in London when World War II was declared. As a very young cadet, Warner cycled around the countryside delivering messages. Then one day she had an encounter with a ‘doddlebug’, an unmanned plane designed to crash and burn, that left her red-faced.

results.title: The Traveller
results.creator_credit: John Hansen, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: John Hansen’s war experience really started after World War II. Having been seconded into the US Navy, John was there to celebrate in the streets of California when the war ended. Then he travelled the world, transporting a variety of things, from war brides to coal. In the end, the world became his classroom.
